title: Academy stars glow
story: THE second British Savate Junior Championships and NI Open were held recently at St Patricksrsquo Hall, Bryansford.Fighters from Northern Ireland, UK, Republic of Ireland, Canada and Japan attended to compete for gold.With over  fights on the day, competition for British Junior and Northern Ireland open titles were at the highest level.Local British Junior Championship winners are as follows: Callum Cawley, Jake Kearney, Oran James Denvir, Rebecca Coyle, Chloe McPolin, Liam Cawley, Oran Denvir, Callum Miller, Oisin Morgan and Josh Smith.Special awards on the day: best junior U-, Ryan McCourt best U-, Odhran Doyle Phil Neil fighter of the tournament, Corey McCullough Jim Fettes Warrior Trophies junior, Arron Connors, senior, Nicky Doyle..prettyPhoto

title: Ardglass buzzing following Irish fisheries decision
story: A LOCAL politician has welcomed confirmation that Ardglass fishermen can operate in Dundalk Bay following a recent decision by the Irish government.It has enacted legislation which allows local fishermen and their counterparts in Kilkeel and Portavogie to fish in southern Irish waters after an agreement was signed by the Irish Cabinet.Cllr Curran said Ardglass harbour is ldquobuzzing with all forms of economic activity, including fish processing.He said that for the past few years, Co Down fishermen could not operate in southern Irish waters as per the so-called Voisinage Agreement due to a Dublin Supreme Court judgement which prohibited fishing in Dundalk Bay.While delighted with the decision, Cllr Curran is also keen to see planned work to deepen Ardglass harbour progressed to allow larger vessels to dock at the port to unload.The proposal was suggested by a new development group formed in the village to upgrade the harbour as part of a plan to secure the future of the fishing industry and help kick-start the economic regeneration of Ardglass.Newry, Mourne and Down Council has also allocated pound, to fund a feasibility study on deepening the harbour and a number of other proposed projects in the village.Cllr Curran said deepening he harbour would help accommodate larger herring and mackerel vessels in particular, highlighting the need to upgrade berthing facilities for local trawlers as well.In addition, he explained that deepening the harbour would also ensure vessels are able to put to sea when they want and not have to wait on the right tidal conditions.The local politician also hopes that a second static refrigeration unit can be provided at the harbour to store crabs landed locally before they are transported to ious markets. Cllr Curran said space in an existing refrigeration unit is exhausted and more is required.Meanwhile, former South Down MP, Margaret Ritchie, who recently visited Ardglass, is also pleased that local fishermen can now fish in Dundalk Bay.She thanked the Minister for Fisheries and Marine in Dublin, political colleagues in Daacuteil Eacuteireann and SDLP leader Colum Eastwood for making representations to ensure legislation was enacted.She added: ldquoThis will ensure that fishing, which is the leblood of the Ardglass community, can continue unhindered. This is also good news for the local economy.Development plans for Ardglass include relocating Ardglass trawlers to the an area known locally as the Saw Pit at the village harbour..prettyPhoto

title: Artist chosen to display work at renowned exhibition in Dublin
story: A DOWNPATRICK artist who is the youngest ever member of the Ulster Water Colour Society is to exhibit in Irelandrsquos biggest and most prestigious art exhibition next month.Connor Maguire has recently been selected to show his self-portrait entitled lsquoMan in the Hatrsquo at the Royal Hibernian Academy in Dublin. It will be the second time he has been chosen to exhibit along with Irelandrsquos finest artists.The  year-old mdash who is a former De La Salle High student mdash says his painting is a side profile piece which was completed in oils on canvas. Out of a total of , entries submitted to the exhibition, only  or so are successful.Connor was shortlisted last year for the Zurich Portrait prize where he was only one of  artists throughout Ireland to be up for a winning prize of two thousand euros.This gave him the opportunity to exhibit in the National Gallery of Ireland which he describes as being ldquosurreal and a dream come true.Connor said: ldquoOne of my earliest memories is of me scribbling away at a table with my grandfather, Broderick Maguire.ldquoMy grandfather, an accomplished draughtsman, carpenter, designer and painter, could do anything that he applied himself to and introduced me to pencil drawing and charcoal. He inspired and captivated me, seeing what he could accomplish with a pencil and a paintbrush. I attempted to paint as good as he did and believe Irsquom still trying.Connor continued: ldquoI recall my art teacher at high school, Mr McLaughlin, was a terric influence on me too. It was one of the few classes I actually enjoyed.ldquoAfter A-Levels, I took up art at the University of Ulster and have been painting non-stop since. I won the Chairmanrsquos Award in , and have went on to win the Stephens Award, Anna Cheyne Award and Carnathan Galleries Award.ldquoI work three days a week at the Assumption Grammar as an art technician. I work with the students, helping them explore print making and they seem to love it.Connor also works steadily as a freelance artist, specialising in painting from watercolours to oils, printmaking in the form of woodcuts, linocuts, drawings in charcoal and graphite exhibiting, and in case he might have a spare moment or two, he is a professional picture framer too.Most of Connorrsquos paintings are inspired by themes of portraiture and he has a keen eye for figure and character in familiar settings like a simple family meal. He takes inspiration form the essence of someone which he can capture through some serious study.Taking part in the exhibition, which is now in its th year, is another stepping block to Connor gaining recognition on the international stage where interest has been coming from American art curator, Didi Menendez and the RJD Gallery in New York.Both notable art critics and buyers who he has been in contact with could well result in him exhibiting further afield.Connor has also took part in BBC Radio  programmes talking about his work with broadcasting journalists, Perminder Khatkar and Helen Marks.Last year he featured on BBC rsquos lsquoThe Arts Showrsquo talking about his work with Marie Louise Muir.He says it was a ldquocool feeling to be featured alongside actor Ciaran Hynds who was featured in the same programme.Connor was shortlisted as Artist of the Year in  in association with Artists  Illustrators Magazine, exhibiting in Londonrsquos prestigious Mall Galleries alongside some of Britainrsquos greatest artists.He was also shortlisted as Artist of the Year in  with the same magazine. winning the West Dean College Award exhibiting again in the Mall Galleries in London.This RHA exhibition will catapult Connor further than he can imagine and said hersquod like to concentrate on portraiture and introduce more figures into the paintings on the theme of realism and experiment on learning new things in printmaking with woodcuts and etching.More of Connorrsquos work can be viewed on his website www.connormaguire..prettyPhoto

title: Bid to boost tourism in Downpatrick area
story: MORE emphasis on tourism promotion across Downpatrick and Lecale has the potential to signicantly enhance the districtrsquos economy, according to a UUP candidate in tomorrowrsquos local council election.Alexander Burgess, who is contesting one of the five seats up for grabs in the Downpatrick DEA, believes more needs to be done to make the most of the arearsquos unique link with St Patrick.Mr Burgess, who was recently joined by his party leader, Robin Swann, on a visit to the centre dedicated to Irelandrsquos patron saint in Downpatrick, is confident that furthering St Patrickrsquos links with Downpatrick and wider Lecale can help promote new business opportunities, including hotel and bed and breakfast accommodation.He is also delighted that planning permission was recently secured for a major new hotel at the site of the former Abbey Lodge development at the Belfast Road on the outskirts of the town.ldquoTourism is the districtrsquos number one economic driver and we are blessed with so many fantastic places to visit in Downpatrick and across the wider district, said Mr Burgess.ldquoMany areas would give all they had to have such an important link with St Patrick. Downpatrick boasts Irelandrsquos only centre dedicated to him but I believe more needs to be done to fully exploit the tourism potential the patron saint offers us.Mr Burgess said additional overnight accommodation in Downpatrick and Lecale was crucial to assisting any new drive to encourage more people to visit and learn about Patrick and the arearsquos rich Patrician heritage.He said having spoken to many people during his election canvass, it is clear there is simply not enough tourism accommodation at present.ldquoIt is rather ironic that while Newry, Mourne and Down Council has quite rightly put tourism at the top of its agenda, there is simply not enough accommodation for people to stay. It is an issue that needs to be addressed, continued Mr Burgess.ldquoThere are already thousands of people visiting the St Patrick Centre every year and how great it would bethere were more places for them to stay to fully exploit what the area has to offer. We already have the Ballydugan Mill hotel on the outskirts of the town and a number of bed and breakfast providers, but we need to capitalise on the lucrative overnight market by providing more bed spaces.Mr Burgess said he hopes that when day-trip tour operators arrange visits to the St Patrick Centre that they will allow additional time for tourists to visit town centre shops, cafes and restaurants..prettyPhoto

title: Burgess calls for new centre to be opened
story: NEWRY, Mourne and Down Council has been asked to open Saintfieldrsquos new community centre immediately.The call has been issued by Rowallane councillor Robert Burgess, who is concerned that weeks after work on the eagerly-anticipated Belfast Road centre was completed, the entrance gates remain locked and the ultra-modern facility lies unused.On the eve of tomorrowrsquos local government election, the Recorder understands that while several opening dates were suggested, agreement could not be reached between the ious parties and that the new centre is not expected to open until the end of this month or early June at the earliest.Newry, Mourne and Down Council is scheduled to hold its annual meeting on May  and it is understood that the new centre will not open before then.A local authority spokesman said as the organisation is currently operating under the restrictions of purdah mdash imposed in the lead-up to an election and which restricts councils from making major announcements ndash the opening will not take place until after the local government poll.Cllr Burgess insists he sees no reason why the centre was not opened before now.ldquoIt is my understanding having spoken to senior council officials that all the work has been completed and it is simply a case of opening the centre. I have also been told that the centre could have opened in February. We are now in May and the entrance gates remain locked. This simply isnrsquot on, he declared.ldquoThe delay in opening a centre which the people of Saintfield helped deliver is inexcusable in my book. Over poundm has been invested in the project and while building work has been completed, the cross-community facility remains closed.Cllr Burgess said there was ample time to arrange the official opening of the centre before purdah kicked in and ahead of tomorrowrsquos election.ldquoWhen the council finally gets around to opening a centre which it has allowed to remain closed for several months, it is essential that it invites all those associated with the project, in particular, those involved with the proposal from the outset.ldquoA lot of people have invested considerable time and effort in this project and it is vital their collective efforts are recognised at the official opening.Cllr Burgess added: ldquoThe people of Saintfield and indeed further afield are perplexed as to why the centre has not opened. Perhaps after purdah ends, Newry, Mourne and Down Council will tell the districtrsquos ratepayers why there has been such an extraordinarily y and, in my opinion, totally unnecessary delay.A local authority spokesman confirmed that no date has yet been agreed for the official opening of the new community centre in Saintfield.He added: As the Council is now operating under the restrictions of lsquopurdahrsquo the centre will not open until after the local council elections have taken place..prettyPhoto

title: Call to begin work on Ballynahinch by pass
story: CALLS have been issued for a start on work on Ballynahinchrsquos new poundm by-pass.It comes just days after major gridlock on the main approach roads to the market town over the Easter holiday period in Ballynahinch which is used as a gateway by visitors to Newcastle and the wider Mournes area in particular.Roads officials say they are keen to get on with the job of building the near two-mile by-pass linking the Belfast and Newcastle roads, with Rowallane Ulster Unionist candidate, Walter Lyons, insisting this must happen now.As part of the multi-million project, major new roundabouts are proposed at the Belfast Road junction with the Saintfield Road and at the Newcastle Road junction with the Downpatrick Road in Ballynahinch.Mr Lyons said the by-pass must be delivered not only to ease town centre gridlock in Ballynahinch, but to encourage new investment and attract more visitors to the area.ldquoThere is no doubt that traffic congestion in the town centre is an impediment to new retail and commercial investment in Ballynahinch and it must be so frustrating for people from Belfast and other areas who have to make their way through the town during bank and public holidays and over the summer to sit in long tailbacks, he said.Mr Lyons, who was recently joined by UUP leader Robin Swann who was visiting the town, said the campaign for the townrsquos by-pass started  years ago and that the scheme must now be delivered.ldquoMoney has been made available for other major road schemes in Northern Ireland while Ballynahinch continues to wait, he declared. ldquoThe congestion in the town centre was as bad as it has been for many years on Easter Monday and we need to address the issue.ldquoIt is clear that the congestion problem is not only impacting on investment in the town but local tourism. My fear is that people will not want to come to our districtthey are continually caught in traffic snarl-ups.Mr Lyons said log-jammed streets could also impact on the ability of the emergency services to respond to major incidents, should one arise.He added: ldquoCongestion in Ballynahinch impacts on a much wider area yet progress on delivering the much-needed by-pass is painfully slow. It is my understanding that the project cannot move to the procurement and construction stages until the necessary funding is available. This needs to happen.ldquoWe need a financial commitment to build the road to benefit the entire district. The congestion is not solely a Ballynahinch problem but,solved, has the capacity to provide major benefits. We have been told that the scheme is shovel ready so letrsquos get on with the job of building the road.Mr Lyons said thatelected to Newry, Mourne and Down Council, delivering the scheme will be one of his key priorities. He said delivering the proposed by-pass must also be a council priority..prettyPhoto

title: Doubles all round for Wexford men
story: IT was cold and windy at Taylorstown, near Poyntzpass, on Saturday for the annual Newry Point-to-Point races.It proved to a good meeting for Wexford with Barry OrsquoNeil, Jamie Codd and Colin Bowe all recording doubles and also for the Doyle brothers, Donnchadh and Sean.OrsquoNeilrsquos brace saw him record his rd winner of the season, while Codd was chalking up his th success in the All-Ireland ridersrsquo table.Coddrsquos double puts him on the  winner mark in the Northern Ireland Ridersrsquo Regional title race, three ahead of Noel McParlan and Rob James.OrsquoNeil and Bowe got off the mark for the day in the Derrylecka Bedding Centre maiden race for five year-old geldings, the second race of the day.Here, the partnership scored with Cremant, winning in good style from Codd on McGarry, owned by Christine McKnight and trained by her husband, Neil, at Loughbrickland. Third was Snowpiercer, ridden by James OrsquoRourke in place of Rob James.The duo then went on to win the third race, the Seven Stars maiden race for five year-old and upwards mares, with Alice OrsquoByrne coming home seven s clear of Codd on Raddle and Hum. The consistent Moylass and Ben Crawford took third place.Coddrsquos first victory came in the Boydrsquos Stores open race that saw seven go to post.A piece of history was made when his mount Kruzhlinin, owned by Camilla Sharples, who is travelling head girl to Gordon Elliott, became the first horse to win nine races in a season.OrsquoNeil set out to make all on recent Loughbrickland winner Sambremont, but had to be content with a fourth-placed finish. Codd sent his mount clear after the last to beat former champion point-to-pointer Anseanachai Cliste, ridden for the first time by Noel McParlan. John Woodsrsquo Bridgetrsquos Pet, ridden by Harley Dunne, was third.Codd then made all on Amalfi Doug in the Lynda Hughes memorial maiden race for six year-old and upwards geldings. Second past the judge was Bronco Bill, well ridden by Michael Molloy with Pyrios and Barry OrsquoNeil third.The winner is trained in Meath by Jim Dreaper, who was represented at the meeting by his son Tom, who said post-race: ldquoJob done.The best finish of the day came in the Philip McCabe Quantity Surveyor one-winner race with three horses flashing past the post, locked together.Victory went to Getaman, ridden by Derek OrsquoConnor, who has had little success on the local circuit this season. Second was Gold Time, ridden by Kevin Corrigan for his father, Martin. A head back in third was Clondaw Nell, ridden by Noel McParlan.Colin McKeever trains the winner for Wilson Dennison at the ownerrsquos estate in Templepatrick.With  of the  entries declared in the Dennison Commercials four year-old maiden race, it had to be ided.The first ide saw Evander, trained in Wexford by Donnchadh Doyle and ridden by stable jockey Rob James, win from Battle of Actium with long time leader Clondaw Pretender, third.In the second ision Kearney Hill and Noel McParlan led over the last fence, but crashed out on landing, leaving Dancewiththewind and James Walsh as winners.Just like Evander in the previous race, the winner is trained in Wexford under the care of Sean Doyle, Donnchadhrsquos brother. Second was Steinkrause in the colours of Ards owner Michael Cave with Seeing Blind, third.The Mid-Antrim meeting will make ato Broughshane this weekend with the cancelled Easter meeting, organised by East Antrim. taking place on May ,At Sligo on Sunday, Spa owner trainer Victor Wilson, who is a farrier, saddled his first winner in a long time when his charge, Mon Storm, with Donnie McInerney in the saddle, won as   favourite.It is interesting to note that the green and white colours used by Victor and his late father, George, from Dromore, were first registered many years ago.Victor told me a while back that he still has the original colours that were in fact an Irish international football shirt with the number covered by the white diamond mdash Victorrsquos uncle was a top footballer in his day..prettyPhoto

title: Downpatrick accountancy firm opens new Belfast office
story: LEADING chartered accountancy firm M B McGrady  Co has recently opened a new Belfast office.Headquartered in Downpatrick, the firm has relocated from its University Street base in the city to the Lisburn Road, creating four new jobs.The company says the office move cements a strong year for the business and is a commitment to its focus on future growth.The four new job roles take the companyrsquos head count to over , spilt across the companyrsquos three offices in Downpatrick, Belfast and Newtownards.Established almost  years ago in Downpatrick, M B McGrady  Co Chartered Accountants is one of Northern Irelandrsquos leading practices, with the company headed up by directors, Mal McGrady, Conaill McGrady and Seamus McLernon.ldquoThe past year has witnessed signicant growth for our company as we prepared for the major changes introduced by HMRC with the launch of Making Tax Digital ndash a move that long-term could potentially cause a sht away from the traditional annual tax , said director Mal McGrady.ldquoWe recognised the challenges that this would present to the accountancy sector and to our clients and set about establishing a specic ision to help clientsrsquo transitions to online accounting.The new ision, which consists of a team of five, is being spearheaded by Conaill McGrady, Director of M B McGrady  Co Chartered Accountants.Reflecting on the businessrsquos expansion and launch of the new ision, Conaill said making tax digital is one of the biggest changes in accountancy in a generation.ldquoWe realised how signicant this would be to both our team and clients and our Making Tax Digital ision was established to both educate and encourage our clients to transition to cloud-based software in order to prepare for the change, he explained.ldquoReflecting the developments in accountancy, our business has also grown considerably. We had outgrown our previous home and felt that the time was right to invest extensively in our Belfast practice, with a bright and shiny new office for our growing team.With a focus on developing local specialist talent, M B McGrady  Co. Chartered Accountantsrsquo says its new Belfast base will provide the company with the opportunity to further grow its workforce over the coming years.In addition, the company is committed to leading the way in delivering digital tax and online accounting services, and helping clients take full advantage of rapidly improving business-friendly accountancy software to streamline their financial operations.With offices in Downpatrick, Belfast and Newtownards, M B McGrady  Co now offers accountancy, payroll, audit and tax services across the region, including specialist services for agricultural and charity businesses..prettyPhoto

title: East Down AC thrive at London Marathon
story: THERE is no such thing as an easy marathon, but as London Marathon is so dficult to get into, in the first place, almost all that do make it to the start are already feeling like they have achieved a goal.Runners are assured of the race of their letime in terms of a memorable experience and many go for the spectacle rather than to chase times as the sheer numbers on the roads can make it dficult to stick to a plan.East Downrsquos Gordy Graham had trained under coach Ryan Maxwellwith precision and dedication, but was realistic enough to know that on the day anything could happen. What did happen, though, was the stuff of dreams.He took a whopping six minutes off his PB and his pacing was textbook, averaging . seconds per mile. Even better, he soaked up the atmosphere and came away saying that it had surpassed his expectations.His club mates, who had tracked him throughout, were as pleased as he was and he was quick to note that the support of fellow members had been a real boost.Having reached halfway in .., Gordy was in no mood to let a possible PB slip through his fingers and though he failed to nail a negative split, it was only by a matter of a few seconds, and perfectly forgivable.His time of .. is something special and deserves the utmost respect. Congratulations, Gordy. And I for one would not begrudge you that beer before you go home as you suggested after the race.Marguerite Robinson was the lucky recipient of the EDAC club ballot back in December and as soon as she heard, she embarked on a schedule to ensure that she made the most of the place.She certainly could not be faulted in her preparation nor in her execution. She had the misfortune to contract a chest infection in the week leading up, but the option of deferral and having to re-do all those training miles spurred her on and she did well to finish in ...Helen and Phillip Vint are old hands at London and yet both confirm that the emotion of the event is still as fresh each time.Phillip was slightly off hand about his worthy .. as this is not a PB by any means, but he should know that to keep banging out sub . marathons is a huge achievement.He had contemplated a somewhat faster run, though, but after coasting along for  miles he was attacked by cramps, so, basically jogged the last nine miles and lives to fight another day.Helen, on the other hand, was over the moon with her .. and rightly so, in what she has described as positively her last ever marathon run.Carmel Tumeltywe spotted at Canary Wharf, though, in a dferent time zone to husband Francis, who was also seen flying along on his way to a remarkable ... Nevertheless, she was as happy as he afterwards. Well done to both of you.Itrsquos not by any means as simple for the enthusiastic spectator. Itrsquos equally,not more dficult, to watch this marathon as the only way to get around the route is by judicious use of the underground and DLR railway systems.Not to mention walking miles up and down stairs, steps, escalators and lts, interspersed with bouts of standing still for upwards of two hours.The things we do for our fellow runners. Of course it helps to be spotted by the runner yoursquore looking out foryou can let him her know in advance where yoursquore going to be, provided you stick to that arrangement.We did, in relation to our positioning at the Woolwich Flyover at approx   miles.The only problem was that there was a band of bongo drummers hell bent on drowning out all our cheers. So, not one of our targeted runners saw or heard us.Helen Vint therefore deserves every credit for spotting her lsquorent a mobrsquo group who had decamped to Canary Wharf, but were being similarly frustrated by another set of drummers. She made their day by waving back.Hill and DaleThursday night is Hill and Dale night for many and despite it being holiday week, plus the British Championships to come a few days later, there was a decent turnout of .Weather-wise, it was not as pleasant as the previous weeks and it was gusty and chilly at the higher points.Eight EDAC runners made the journey to Slieve Martin with Niall Gibney leading them home in the absence of Gavin Hynds .Niall was th in ., Niamh Kellett retained the F top spot for the third week in a row in th place, Jonny Kelly was th in a shade over  minutes as he races himself back into fitness.Another repeat winner was the ever modest Brian Hamilton as he secured the O prize once again, but at least he made the photo this week. Lisa Milligan and John Manley ran together, but John was the perfect gentleman and let Lisa cross the line first in th to his th place.Patricia Galloway is now an lsquoold handrsquo at this and was th, while Janine Murray was a trooper coming in th. It is the ones who are finding it hard that deserve the congratulations in my opinion and Hill and Dales provides plenty of scope for suffering.Firmus SeriesAlso on Thursday night there was a Firmus Energy Fab  Track Meet at MPT.A good turnout from EDAC juniors meant there was plenty to watch and many competed more than once. Performance of the night goes to Lauren Madine in the U- m.She kept her head in the first few laps and then opened the throttle to sail into the lead in a PB of ..Anna Gardiner hung on well to take third spot in the same race . In a valiant effort in the U- m, Jodi Foster also made podium in third place.Other results as follows based on times of all heats: U- m, Alex Robinson th  in . minutes U- cricket ball throw, Alex Robinson th  U- m, Kari Foster th U- long jump, Kari Foster th U- m, Ollie Robinson th  , Kieran Trainor thU- m, Ollie Robinson th U- m, Kara Trainor th senior m, Edie Carroll th  .Ballynahinch Lions kSaturday bore the brunt of Storm Hannah and unfortunately Ballynahinch Lions k was postponed as a result. The fierce wind and heavy rain was not conducive to a family fun run and although the k runners may have been hardier, the decision was made to seek an alternative date for safety reasons.Mourne HighlineAt noon on Saturday the Mourne Highline, which is included in the British Mountain Running Championships, did go ahead, albeit with an alteration to the route.The course includes a fast climb up the Granite Trailas far as the Quarry and on via the Glen river path to the summit of Commedagh and then a technical and somewhat hazardous descent.It was a tough one by all accounts and the fact that the first  places went to runners from England, Scotland and Wales indicates the kudos that is attributed to this race. Neil Andrews took an impressive rd place in  hour . Gavin Hynds and Niall Gibney slugged it out against the elements and were rewarded with st and th positions respectively, just a couple of minutes between them. There were  finishers in all so their placings are noteworthy indeed.LondonMini-MarathonThree girls from East Down were selected to run in the London Mini Marathon as a result of their performances in the Ulster Schoolsrsquo Cross Country series mdash a three mile run down the Mall in advance of the main London Marathon.To have the chance to run in front of the huge hordes of spectators is special indeed. Kirsti Foster, who was also there last year, was looking to improve on her performance from , but now in the U- event.Anna Gardiner and Lucy Foster had no idea what to expect. In the end, all three girls did themselves proud.Kirsti completed in ., which was nearly  seconds quicker than last year and put her th overall and the first of the NI athletes home in that age group.In the U- age group Lucy was thand Anna was thand they were second and third NI athletes home. These performances are praiseworthy and endorse their selection. Well done girls.Eams SeriesCloser to home, Clare Carson was keeping herself on track for Belfast Marathon and entered the East Antrim Marathon Series in Greenisland which had a k option.She was delighted to come home as first female and will take this as a welcome confidence boost ahead of Sunday.Keira Proctor-Amos took part in inter squadron athletics at Mary Petersrsquo Track on Sunday and came away with two medalsand qualies for regionals in Scotland.This weekendItrsquos an historic day for the River Rock Belfast City Marathon when the event takes place on Sunday for the first time ever, starting in the grounds of Stormont Castle and organisers are delighted to say that the total running the full marathon distance is almost double that of last yearrsquos entry. East Down sends its best wishes to everyone taking part..prettyPhoto

title: Every post a winning one for Lynch on Slieve Martin
story: NEWCASTLErsquoS Seamus Lynch picked up his second win on the bounce when taking the honours in the third race of the Hill and Dale series in Rostrevor on Thursday night.Preparation for the Slieve Martin run went reasonably smoothly. Plenty of people had kindly offered to volunteer, the course was marked, and everything ready.Unfortunately, the first aid kit that had gone missing on the first race had still not turned up. The kit had been replaced, a defibrillator was still not available.A lot of discussion was had around how a first aid kit could go missing and where on earth it could be.With the British Championships at the weekend,  runners registeredas runners were sensibly tapering in preparation for Saturday.Conditions at registration were pleasant, with the sun shining ndash it was a dferent story on the summit. Maybe it was a sign of things to come with storm Hannah approaching mdash visibility was poor with strong gusts making the temperatureseveral degrees. Conditions underfoot were slippery from the rain earlier that day.Just before .pm the runners lined up to listen to the usual briefing by Stevie Rice and the race was started promptly.The race starts with a deceptively steep start through the trees. From the off, Lynch took the lead with Mari Troengleading the ladies. Seamy remained unchallenged and held his position all the way to the finish, coasting across the line.Colm Murtaghfollowed in second place overall and first V.Luke Russellhad a strong run, taking the final podium spot in third.Rivalries were fierce slightly further back, with Richard Bellleading Sean Russellinto the finish for fth, but it was Sean who edged it.There was just  seconds that separated Newcastle AC club mates John Kelly and Pete Grant for first V with John getting the category win.Another close race between Deon McNeillyand Jim Brownfor first V, with Deon holding on to the lead. Just ahead of Deon was first V, Dominic McGreevyhaving a strong run.In the ladiesrsquo race, Newcastle ACrsquos Mari Troeng lead the race from start to finish, with Mourne Runnerrsquos Lynne Spence having a fantastic run to finish second. Newry ACrsquos Sarah Quinn finished third.We then had Barbara Hunter , over from England and running her first Hill and Dale. Hazel McLaughlintalked her into running the race while she was over. I donrsquot know how Hazel described the race to Barbara _ Hazelrsquos idea of easy is usually far from it!Once sweeper John lsquoButcherrsquo Kelly had arrived, it was off to the Cloughmore Inn, for refreshments, food and presentations, including the much sought-after HD mug spot prizes.Race organisers would like to thank everyone that gave up their time to help make another successful race, in particular the marshals out on the hill who had to endure cold conditions.For those that are still wondering about what happened to the first aid kit, well you will be relived to hear the kitwas found left mysteriously by registration - apparently, it was in the boot of someonersquos car.Tomorrow nightrsquos weekrsquos race s to Slieve Binnian, the only summit finish in the series.Remember to bring your number and full body cover..prettyPhoto

title: Farms open to the public for weekend initiative
story: FIVE local farms are competing in the forthcoming Bank of Ireland open farm weekend initiative.They include Castlescreen Farm near Downpatrick, Millbank Farm in Killinchy, Carryduffrsquos Mossbrook Road farm, the Walls Farm outside Bryansford and Churchview Farm in Ballyward, outside Castlewellan.Members of the public are being encouraged to experience their local farm for free in one of the biggest awareness initiatives of its kind in Northern Ireland.The initiative mdash held over the weekend of June  and  mdash highlights where food comes from and the benefits of eating local, as well as giving visitors the chance to sample the world-class ingredients that are produced in Northern Ireland.It is hoped that the open farm weekend will attract upwards of , visitors from rural and urban towns and cities to  farms across the Province.Each farm will be providing fun activities throughout the weekend such as petting farms, pony rides, competitions, live music and demonstrations.Ahead of the event, Bank of Ireland open farm weekend Ulster Farmersrsquo Union deputy president, David Brown, said now more than ever, farmers needed to be telling their story.ldquoThis initiative is a great way for us to engage with the public and show them the industry up-close, he continued. ldquoThe initiative has become an important part of our work, allowing us to reach out to the non-farming community to promote the vital work of farmers across Northern Ireland.ldquoMany farms have been handed down through the generations, passing on skills and looking after livestock and the land. The event this summer allows us to celebrate the inidual farmrsquos story both in the present and in the past.Bank of Ireland agriculture manager, Richard Primrose, said it was great to see  farms volunteering to represent their industry this year.He added: ldquoWe have a good mix of existing farms who have taken part before and new farms opening their gates for the first time to take part in open farm weekend.ldquoWe are fortunate in Northern Ireland to have such wonderful local food and drink produce and this initiative helps the general public trace their food story back to the field and farm.Mr Primrose added: ldquoThese dedicated farmers are playing a commendable role in communicating the important job farmers play in the supply chain to a wider audience and we all owe them a debt of thanks for their effort and commitment.Visitors can plan their trip and find out what activities are available at each farm by visiting www.openfarmweekend..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C May 1%2C 1979
story: DOWNPATRICK mdash A jobs boom that could provide pound, a week in wages is on the cards for Downpatrick mdashthe Department of Commerce can provide factory accommodation in a hurry.Two Continental-backed firms have been attracted to the employment-hungry town, but the problem is that only one government advance factory is available for letting.The big question is this. Does it go to a firm which pledges  jobs for men, plus work for up to  more in ancillary industries mdash four of which already exist in the area mdash or does it go to a cheese manufacturing concern which promises  jobs for women It is understood that production machinery already ordered by the larger company is scheduled for delivery in nine monthsrsquo time and thatthe Downpatrick site is not made available in the meantime the firm will set up plant in Southern Ireland.The firm does not wish to be identied by name, but itrsquos formation arises out of unexpectedly big sales of Belgian-made furniture in the UK and the Irish Republic.The parent firm is one of Europersquos leading manufacturers of upmarket household furniture, as well as hospital furnishings.They have an annual turnover of pound million and began exporting to Britain and Ireland three years ago. Their share of the market has grown to such an extent that they have decided to begin manufacturing here.NEWCASTLE mdash Mrs Ann Davey received a double shock on Saturday. First, her Chrysler Alpine car was stolen and then it drove straight past her on the Hilltown to Newry Road.Mrs Davey, of Brook Cottage, Newcastle, had reported the theft to local police and, after having seen her car being driven later in the day, she again contacted the police station.The Newcastle police finally found the car abandoned on a quiet road at Fofanny where it was obstructing traffic. The car was ed undamaged to its owner, but three local youths are assisting police with their enquiries.In one way Mrs Davey gained out of the incident mdash the car was recovered with a full petrol tank.KILLYLEAGH mdash The condition of Killyleaghrsquos roads and footpaths came under strong criticism at the monthly meting of Killyleagh, Shrigley and District Town Committee.It was claimed by the committee that there has been no replacement kerbstones or resurfacing to the townrsquos footpaths in over  years and this gave the town an overall shabby appearance.In particular they put five streets under the microscope mdash Cross Street, Shore Street, Irish Street, High Street and Catherine Street mdash and lashed out that the footpaths were not only shabby, but dangerous and needed better attention.in Irish Street one pothole was described as hazardous and the committee have called for immediate action.The well-attended meeting received good news following their demand for action on repairing the footpaths from Killyleagh to Shrigley and at Cuan Beach. They were informed by the Department of Environment that they will take action with work starting soon and both projects may possibly be completed before the end of the summer.The unsatisfactory situation where schoolchildren attending the local high school are continually soaked when sea water lashes over the sea wall at Seaview Road was also discussed in some depth. The committee are anxious to find a solution to the problem and will talk to the DoE about widening the road.PORTAFERRY mdash Members of Portaferry Development Association have claimed that Ards Borough Council has conned them over plans for a sewage disposal scheme in the town.This week they held an emergency meeting in St Columbarsquos Secondary School to consider the situation. Among those who attended were Lord Dunleath and local councillor Paddy Doherty.The Association says that in  the council proposed a new scheme by which sewage would be treated through filter beds before being pumped into Strangford Lough.A spokesman for the association said that the filter beds have been scrapped from the scheme and that raw sewage is now to be pumped into the lough.ldquoWe genuinely feel that we have been conned by the council, he said. ldquoWe found out about the change in the plans too late.BALLYNAHINCH mdash The boys of Ballynahinch High School have handed over a colour TV set to Dr Barnardorsquos in Belfast. The boys purchased the  set with more than pound which they raised in a -hour sponsored football match earlier in the year.The idea to organise the match came from the boys and they were supervised by four members of staff.The boys were David Crainey, Kenneth Geddis, Francis Strain, Brian Crainey, Kenneth Hall, Mark Crawford, Graham Early, Stephen Early, Alan Davis and Walter Lyons.DUNDRUM mdash Dundrum Regatta and Spots Committee met on Tuesday night to finalise their plans for this yearrsquos regatta , which will be held on Saturday, June .The traditional time for the regatta was early August, but this year the committee decided to go for date in June when there is a better chance of good weather.To prepare the village for the annual event, the regatta dance will be held on Midsummerrsquos Night. a top band and a well known personality have been booked for the occasion.The main events will take place on Saturday, June , and the community are ing to the old style of a century ago, which will involve all ages. Yacht racing will take place on a newly designed course with greatly improved prizes.Negotiations are well advanced to bring in a group of advanced water skiers to give a demonstration and in the evening a band will lead the fancy parade to the sports field.CARRYDUFF mdash Foundation work was completed this week on a project which will provide Carryduff with a modern and spacious new library.When complete the library will have a full range of books and tapes and a multi-purpose area for exhibitions and evening use by the local community.It will form part of a proposed community area comprising an old peoplersquos home, nursery school and landscaped pedestrian way.It will be open initially on three afternoons and three evenings each week and every Saturday morning. It is hoped that art exhibitions, craft displays and travelling exhibitions will be held.DRUMANESS mdash Police are investigating two break-ins in the Drumaness area. Late on Tuesday or early on Sunday morning thieves broke into to the Co-op store in the village and among the items taken were tools and cigarettes valued at pound. The following night thieves also entered Drumaness Mill where they removed wiring and piping.CROSSGAR mdash The War Memorial Hall in Crossgar was packed to capacity on two nights last week for the eighth annual concert in connection with Crossgar Choral Society.The presentation this year was lsquoSongs from the Showsrsquo and solo parts were taken by Anne Sage, Jean Montgomery, Maureen Bingham, Avril Thompson, Ann Hay, Marie McHugh and Messrs Albert Sage, David Wilson, Jack Breheny and Roy Bennett. Three Little Maids was sung by Claire McHugh, Catherine Sage and Donna Morgan.Mr W A Rourke expressed a comprehensive vote of thanks to all who had ontrinuted to the enormous success, especially Mrs Stella Kingand Mrs Angela Bradley .CASTLEWELLAN mdash Police are investigating a recent spare of sheep and cattle worrying in the Castlewellan area. Dogs have been spotted chasing livestock and police have issued a warning that owners must keep their pets under control..prettyPhoto

title: Inspirational young people recognised at special ceremony
story: NEWRY, Mourne and Down Council has recognised a group of inspirational young people at its sixth annual YAFTA Awards.The event, which was a celebration of a programme between the Youth Council and Newry, Mourne and Down Council, took place at the Canal Court Hotel and Spa recently.The glamorous event saw  people celebrate both the young people and the projects they are involved in.Council chairman Mark Murnin said he was delighted to celebrate the achievements of ldquoour outstanding young people.He remarked: ldquoThe YAFTAS were specically created by the youth council and supported by the council and the Education Authority to recognise the unsung heroes of within our community who do not get the recognition they deserve.ldquoThese awards shine a positive light on our young people and the work they do.He added: ldquoThe competition this year made shortlisting winners more dficult as our young people across the district have been involved in some fantastic youth work programmes, including volunteering.ldquoBoth the young people and their achievements deserve to be highlighted and recognised.There were seven award categories recognising dferent aspects of community and voluntary service.The Voice of Young People Award went to Cathal McCann, Emma Cunningham and Brooklyn Flanagan, three pupils from St Malachyrsquos High School in Castlewellan.These three students wanted to do more to raise awareness of student emotional wellbeing. They came up with the idea to host a fundraising event within their school involving students wearing a bright jumper to school on Blue Monday, January .They raised pound which went to supporting early intervention strategies towards young people. As a result, these students appeared in a video which was created by Action for Children and was shown to MPs and MLAs at Stormont to raise awareness of mental health issues towards young people and the need for extra government funding.The runner-up in this category was Lara OrsquoNeill, Head Girl at St Maryrsquos High School in Newry.The Innovation and Creativity Award category was won by the Slurrysafe team of Conal Murray, Matthew Isaac and Connor Kelly, from South Eastern Regional College in Downpatrick.The boys, all from farming backgrounds met at an engineering course and decided to tackle the risks associated from slurry by designing a slurry alarm after an incident affected one of their families.Their design dfers by linking the alarm to the tractor engine so that when the alarm sounds, power to the tractor is cut off which stops the slurry mixer. This alerts the farmer and a sensor sends a message to a mobile phone of the risk.The runners-up in this category were Assumption Community Link mdash students at Assumption Grammar School who have been innovative in establishing a community link with local primary schools in the Ballynahinch area.They have supported children in the local area who have high levels of illiteracy and innumeracy and struggle with socio-economic hardship. They provided taster sessions in Irish and Spanish when the primary schools were informed funding for languages was no longer available.A third dimension of the community link is the partnership with Knockevin Special School in Downpatrick where they work in the areas of music and drama.The Inspirational Young Person Award went to Cormac Savage, from Downpatrick, is a student at St Patrickrsquos Grammar School where he has been involved in civic education and getting students involved in the democratic process.Cormac has co-ordinated the Make Your Mark Campaign in South Down, a youth campaign that decided on what issues the Youth Parliament should campaign on. Cormac contacted school principals directly and single handedly secured involvement from five principals and over , local students.Cormac went on to represent , young people as a member of the Youth Parliament with % of the vote. He delivered a speech on the subject of homelessness which was awarded the Paul Boskett MBE Award. Cormac is a volunteer at his Mid Down MS support group and assists with Loughinisland amateur drama group, coaching young children in drama. This summer Coramac is planning to travel to Cambodia for three weeks to teach English, plant trees and build homes in some of the poorest communities in the world.In the Young Carer Award category the runners-up were Downpatrick sisters Antonia and Aoise OrsquoGoan, who look after their grandmother, Mrs Margaret Walsh.Other recipients on the night were as follows:Good Relations Award: winners, Leaders of Hope and Harmony, Kilkeel runners-up, Newtownhamilton TBUC in the Community, Newtownhamilton.Young Carer Award: winner, Ben McGlade, Newry.Community Safety Award: winner, Regener, Slieve Gullion runners-up, Newry Fire Cadets.Inspirational Young Person Award: runner-up, Hannah Kelly, Newry.Inclusion Award: winners, Wonder Youth Group and Newry Youth Forum runners-up, St. Oliver Plunkett Inclusion Group, Crossmaglen.The event was supported by Newry, Mourne and Down District Council, the Executive Office, the Policing and Community Safety Partnership, Specsavers Newry, Education Authority, Education Authority Small Grants, Buttercrane Centre Newry, Newry Clinic PJ OrsquoHarersquos, Carlingford and JP Corry..prettyPhoto

title: Irish government urged to support the Patrician story
story: THE Irish government has been urged to do more to support the Patrician story, not only locally, but across the island.The call was issued by Downpatrick Sinn Fein election candidate Oonagh Hanlon during a visit to the town last week by Taacutenaiste Simon Coveney.He was at the St Patrickrsquos Centre to launch local historian John Killenrsquos new book rsquoThe St Patrickrsquos Treasuryrsquo.Mr Hanlon said Mr Coveney clearly has an interest in Patrician history and the contemporary signicance of St Patrick.She said she was keen to stress to Irelandrsquos deputy head of government that the southern administration has a responsibility to support the protection and enhancement of Patrician history throughout Ireland and locally across St Patrickrsquos Country.ldquoWhilst the Taacutenaistersquos department is supportive of a small number of local programmes, I believe it can do much more to help sustain the huge international interest in Patrician history and the signicance of his contemporary inclusive legacy in our ided society, said Mrs Hanlon.She added: ldquoI look forward to continuing this discussion with the Taacutenaiste in the months ahead and thank him for taking time out of a very busy schedule to engage with local school children, business owners and the wider community in Downpatrick..prettyPhoto

title: Irish Street work delay a ‘disgrace’%2C says Curran
story: THE major delay in completing work on an environmental improvement scheme in Irish Street in Downpatrick has been branded a ldquodisgrace by a local politician.Councillor Dermot Curran has this week called for an urgent meeting to be arranged between traders and senior officials from a number of government departments involved in the project to discuss what went wrong and what can be done to ensure the project is completed as soon as possible.Last week the Recorder revealed that Irish Street traders are furious that work on the project is to take more than twice as long to complete than originally planned.Work to provide new paving, street lighting and street furniture was due to complete at the end of March, but contractors will not now be finished their work until the end of June.And, to compound tradersrsquo frustration, once contractors move off site, Irish Street will be completely closed to traffic for a short period to allow the main road to be resurfaced, taking the scheme into July.There have been a series of issues associated with the regeneration scheme with the initial start date delayed as Phoenix Gas took longer than expected to complete its work at this part of the town.Signicant issues have also arisen with the foundations for the blast wall which surrounded the former police base and problems with the sewer network.Cllr Curran wants senior representatives from Newry, Mourne and Down Council and the Departments for Infrastructure and Communities to meet with traders and insists that NI Water must also be represented.ldquoThe public realm scheme has been delayed by over three months, raw sewage has been running down the street and, most shockingly, traders have not been kept abreast of the reasons for the delay, he declared.ldquoThe Irish Street project was due to complete inside three months but it will now be early July and what those responsible for the work do not realise is that businesses are being affected across the town, not just those in Irish Street.Cllr Curran said the delay in completing the scheme is having a major impact on the town centre, revealing that he has heard reports that the number of people using the Irish Street car park has reduced since work on the public realm scheme started.He said with trading conditions dficult enough at the best of times, the last thing business owners need is for the one-way system remaining in place in Irish Street for another two months.ldquoThe delay in completing this scheme is nothing short of disgraceful and questions need answered. In addition, traders should be provided with weekly progress briefings as a matter of courtesy. The fact this has not happened is deeply disappointing, Cllr Curran continued.The local politician said the temporary one-way system is impacting on traffic volumes in St Patrickrsquos Avenue and Market Street in particular, with some shoppers opting to avoid Downpatrick as work on the public realm scheme continues.Cllr Curran also suggested that the delay in delivering the public realm scheme would ldquosimply not be tolerated in any other area. He claimed that taking twice as long to complete a scheme would not be accepted in areas like Newry, Lisburn or Belfast.He declared: ldquoMany businesses in Downpatrick are suffering as the result of an unacceptable delay. The clear evenings are now here, so why canrsquot contractors be asked to work longer to complete the scheme sooner ldquoWhile I accept that the delays may be the result of unexpected circumstances, surely the trick is to come up with imaginative solutions to get the work completed as soon as possible  The suggested completion date at the end of June needs to be reassessed now.Cllr Curran said he plans to contact the ious government departments and agencies to arrange a meeting with Irish Street traders and hopes it will take place as soon as possible..prettyPhoto

title: Newcastle park needs management strategy
story: NEWRY, Mourne and Down Council officials have been asked to develop a management strategy for an open area at the rear of Newcastlersquos Donard Park and adjacent woodland.The request has been made by Mournes councillor Willie Clarke, who recently tabled a council motion urging the local authority to contact the Annesley Estate with a view to leasing land it owns at this part of the town.Cllr Clarke is keen for this to happen to enable the council to maintain what he described as an ldquoattractive area to complement existing amenities in Donard Park.He believes the council can help play a key role in improving the recreational, health and well-being of local people, in tandem with enhancing the resortrsquos tourism potential,the area and its important habitat are managed properly.While his recent motion was referred to the local authorityrsquos Economic Regeneration and Tourism Committee for debate, Cllr Clarke said that,re-elected, one of his key priorities will be shaping the future management of a ldquo fabulous landscape and woodland, preserving it for future generations.He continued: ldquoThe upper green area needs to be incorporated in the future management of Donard Wood, while the pathways and signage for visitors need to be improved for visitors entering the main route used by hill walkers heading into the Mournes to climb Slieve Donard.ldquoIn the short term, I have made representations to council officials to carry out maintenance improvements at the Shanslieve Drive entrance to Donard Park where visitors are greeted by rusting litter bins, council signage dating back to the s and a potholed surface.Cllr Clarke said these are improvements that need to carried out immediately.Also this week, he has called on the local authority to repaint the historic archway at the entrance to Donard Park car park.He said: ldquoRepainting the archway will also improve the appearance and aesthetics of the entrance into Donard Park and I have requested that the work is undertaken as quickly as possible, Cllr Clarke added..prettyPhoto

title: Newcastle rock star’s intimate solo album
story: THE discovery of a random white feather gave The Answerrsquos frontman Cormac Neeson a sign of hope at the most desperate time in his le mdash and the inspiration for his first solo album.The Newcastle rocker has just released a searingly intimate and personal album called White Feather with ten tracks which deal with his eldest son Dabhoacutegrsquos fight to be born and for le itself.Launching at Belfast venue The Black Box on May , the  year-old will give his most stripped back performance as an artist as he tours with the album over the coming months.His old friends, The Unholy Gospel Band, with bass guitarist, Downpatrickrsquos own Eamon Hanlon, will be joining him for the big night.Cormac also has a new single out from the album, Broken Wing, a country-inspired track with blues backing choir that will resonate with people whether they are a parent or not.His rock vocals have given way to a deeper, introspective sound that is still etched with emotion.The  year-old singer, who once toured with rock legends AD DC, says he the experience of nearly losing his son from being born prematurely at  weeks has changed him.Dabhoacuteg, who has Downrsquos Syndrome, weighed only lb oz when he was born. After spending his first four months in a hospital neo-natal unit and undergoing heart surgery on his first birthday, he is now four. Thankfully, Dabhoacuteg has turned the corner despite overcoming serious medical obstacles in his short le.Dabhoacuteg and his  month-old brother, Conall, mean everything to Cormac and his we Louise, who now live in Belfast.ldquoWhenever you have a sick child and you go through an ordeal like that with your family, it does definitely alter your perception and you come out the other side of it changed, said Cormac.ldquoYou just look at le in a dferent way. You appreciate stuff that you never appreciated because yoursquore not sitting in an intensive care unit in the Royal [Victoria Hospital]. Anything is better than that.The couple only had a few weeks to privately celebrate getting pregnant with their first child when Louise had to be rushed into hospital.They initially were advised that pregnancy was lost as it was so early but were told to come back to hospital in a few weeks time.ldquoIt was the longest two weeks in my le, recalls Cormac. ldquoThe night before we were due to go the hospital I went out for a walk in the Mournes. I was a bit raging at the world and screaming up to the heavens asking to be give a sign that everything was going to be ok.ldquoI was literally stopped dead in my tracks with this little splash of white high in a tree. I climbed up into the tree to see what it was and it was a white feather.ldquoI had always been brought up to believe that white feathers symbolised new le. I couldnrsquot believe that I spotted it at that time and brought it back down. I had a feeling then that everything was ok. The next day we went to hospital and sure enough there was this tiny mustard seed on the scan with the most giant heartbeat you ever saw in your le. It was the beginning of what was to be a most tumultuous journey and the beginning of where we are now, having an amazing four-year-old and a baby.ldquoDabhoacuteg really is a warrior. Hersquos been through more than me and most people ever will in their lives.Long-term fans of The Answer may be surprised at one of their leaders heading to Nashville to write and record the album.But as Cormac tells it, itrsquos just the way it was meant to be.He went to the home of country music in  on a songwriting course to help write songs for other artists but ended up literally pouring his heart and pain out in the songs mdash in time-honoured country music fashion.ldquoItrsquos not a country record but you can tell it is recorded in Nashville, said Cormac.ldquoThere is an awful lot of soul to it and a bit of subtley to it as well as it allowed me to express myself in the way that I needed to at this point in my le. I needed to make a record that reflected that switch in the way I see le.The Nashville approach to writing songs was a more reflective experience for Cormac that what he is used to with bandmates Paul Mahon, Mickey Waters and James Heatley.ldquoIt was just a completely dferent approach to songwriting that I had been used to doing for  years with The Answer, said Cormac. ldquoItrsquos a hard rocking blues band and a lot of our songs are written with the volume pedal turned up rfing away, having a good time and letting songs organically develop.ldquoIn Nashville, you sit in a room with two other people and an accustic guitar and you have a long conversation about your le and what you might want to write about. I found once we were locked into the message we wanted to put across in the song everything  fell into place. We basically wrote songs in the morning and recorded in the afternoon as thatrsquos what the studio expected.ldquoA lot of what Irsquom singing about on this record just would not work on a record from The Answer because it wouldnrsquot be appropriate. Rock and roll is loud and le-affirming. While a lot of these songs are le-affirming, they are in a completely dferent way.Cormac assures the bandrsquos devoted following that they have stockpiled a supply of new songs and will be coming out with a new album.Addressing his own personal hiatus, Cormac added: ldquoIrsquom still the same guy I was in The Answer and will be again when The Answer makes our next record. I just needed to get into the right room with the right writers making the right music.White Feather album will be released on April  before a tour kicks off in the UK on May  for a run of seven support shows followed by six Irish headline dates. For show dates visit http:www.cormacneeson or https:www.facebook cormacneesonsolo ..prettyPhoto

title: School of Lifesaving staff complete Makaton course
story: DOWNPATRICK School of Lesaving has been taking part in a new training course.Rhianna Rooney and Yvonne Smyth, who are both senior lesaving teachers at Downpatrick School of Lesaving, attended a Full Makaton for Beginners Course held recently in Castlewellan.Aware of how beneficial the use of Makaton could be to the coaches of DSL, Yvonne approached the course tutor, Cynthia Robinson, with an idea that could assist the lesaving club.In a joint collaboration, a number of lesaving signs and signals were consolidated into a Makaton course specic to lesaving.Yvonne said: ldquoWe are trying to offer inclusiveness within our sport, so we fully understand and appreciate the need for Makaton training.ldquoWe have a team of  senior and junior volunteer coaches, with an additional eight parent helpers, delivering our lesaving skill to approximately  local young people ages from six years up.ldquoWe have had great satisfaction knowing that we can try to reach out to all.Downpatrick School of Lesaving would like to thank Cynthia for her help and support..prettyPhoto

title: Sinn Fein leader McDonald visits Downpatrick
story: SINN Fein president Mary Lou McDonald was in Downpatrick on Monday as part of a visit to the district ahead of tomorrowrsquos local government election.She was welcomed to the town by party representative Oonagh Hanlon and visited the Pepper Johns Community Centre in Church Avenue and the grave of United Irishman Thomas Russell in the grounds of Down Parish Church.The Sinn Fein party leader also visited the grave of St Patrick at Down Cathedral where she met the Dean of Down, the Very Rev Henry Hull, and Dr Tim Campbell, Director of the St Patrick Centre, which is dedicated to Irelandrsquos patron saint.Accompanying the Sinn Fein president were South Down MP Chris Hazzard, Emma Rogan MLA and council election candidates Jordan Madden, who is standing in the Downpatrick DEA with Mrs Hanlon, and Slieve Croobrsquos Cathy Mason.Mrs Hanlon said she was delighted to welcome the party president to Downpatrick where she enjoyed the ldquovery unique and enduring heritage the local area has to offer, also meeting a wide range of local community leaders.ldquoI want to especially thank Alison and everyone at Pepper Johns Community Centre who made Mary Lou feel very welcome. She was clearly in awe at the fantastic work they do for the local community, said Mrs Hanlon.ldquoThanks also to Dean Hull for hosting an extremely engaging visit to Down Cathedral and the world renowned grave of St Patrick.Mrs Hanlon added: ldquoLocal people are understandably very proud of the rich, enduring Patrician heritage in these parts and itrsquos great to see such enthusiasm from yet another national political figure following the recent visit of Taacutenaiste Simon Coveney..prettyPhoto

title: Sizzling Down lift All Ireland title
story: A VIRTUOSO attacking display from Sorcha McCartan and a defensive masterclass from team captain Blanaid Savage enabled Down to lt the All-Ireland B Shield at a cold and wind-swept Inniskeen Grattans, Monaghan, on Saturday afternoon.The final scoreline was a bit rough on a game Meath outfit and two goals from the predatory Saoirse Sands, in as many minutes just before the break, proved the dference between the sides.Down started in a hurry with midfielders Megan OrsquoBoyle and Anna McKee seeing plenty of the ball and they wasted no time in getting their forwards involved.As early as the second minute, Down were awarded a free on the m line.Everyone thought that McCartan would just pop the sliotar over the bar for an easy point, but she had other ideas and blasted a fiercely-hit shot to the back of the net.Down continued to ask all the early questions, but two minutes later they were found wanting at the back and when their defence failed to deal with a Jessica Potterton free, Ciara Foley swooped to bring the sides level with an instinctive finish.McCartan edged Down back in front with a well-taken point, but two unanswered scores, one from the diligent Potterton and one from Sonia Leonard gave Meath a - to - lead after  minutes.That lead didnrsquot last long as the inspirational McCartan effortlessly lofted over a rsquo to level the scores yet again with  minutes gone.Meath were wining a lot of lsquodirty ballrsquo in the engine room, but superb defensive play from Savage and Orlaith OrsquoRourke kept them at bay.However, Potterton converted another free in the st minute to give her side a - to - lead and when Emer Fagan stretched that lead to two points, Down suddenly looked vulnerable.With  minutes gone Bredaghrsquos Aoibhinn Brentnall reduced the leeway before sizzling Sands stunned Meath.Her first goal came in the th minute after the Meath lsquokeeper was unable to clear a lofted effort from Beth Fitzpatrick. Sands struck with all the stealth and power that her dad Noel displayed for Down hurlers for many years as she beat Katie Smith all ends up with a clinical finish.Meath were now on the ropes and Sands delivered a second knock-out blow a minute later when she again ghosted in to direct a McCartan pass to the net and give down a - to - interval lead.Meath had the wind advantage after the break, but it was Down and the unrelenting McCartan who took centre stage.Two sensational points from the Castlewellan teenager, a daughter of former Down All-Ireland medal winner Greg in , stretched Downrsquos lead to seven points with only five minutes of the second half played.All credit to Meath, they steadfastly refused to throw in the towel and a Foley point left them trailing - to - after  minutes.It wax at this stage that Savage played a real captainrsquos role from her central half back role. She was simply imperious, plucking the sliotar out of the air and then sending it forward for her team-mates to chase.Meath went close to giving Down a fright in the rd minute when an explosive shot from Fagan rattled off the crossbar and was cleared to safety, but other than that, little got past Savage.McCartan and Leonard swapped points as the game drew to a close, but Down had no intention of relinquishing their grip on the game and refused to give Meath any more scores.Down: Niamh Sharkey, Orlaith OrsquoRourke, Hannah Toner, Alice Coulter, Isabella OrsquoHare, Blanaid Savage, Niamh Dempster, Megan OrsquoBoyle, Anna McKee, Cerys Clarke, Sorcha McCartan , Saoirse Sands , Gerra McGrattan, Aoibhinn Brentnall , Beth Fitzpatrick. Subs: Aimee Mallon for Toner, Toner for OrsquoRourke, Alanna Hagan for McGrattan, Colleen McConnell, Bronagh Donaghy, Olivia Blaney, Eden Casey, Hannah Duffy, Roisin McPolin, Niamh Burns, Chloe McConville, Caitlin Fitzpatrick, Aoe McCann.Meath: Katie Smith, Caitlin Hamilton, Abbye Donnelly, Sophie Healy, Kate Smith, Aine Cooke, Hazel OrsquoReilly-Higgins, Ellen Brogan, Jessica Potterton , Sonia Leonard , Emer Fagan , Rachael Fraughan, Ellen OrsquoHara, Ciara Foley , Taylor Stack. Subs: Andrea McBride for Brogan, Francesca McKenna for Fraughan.  Down -Meath -ALL-IRELAND MINOR B SHIELD FINAL.prettyPhoto

title: St John’s GAC charity fashion show
story: A FASHION show which evokes the glamorous style worn by your mother or grandmother in the s visits the area on Saturday night.St Johnrsquos GAC in Drumnaquoile is hosting the show from the Living Vintage Company as a fundraiser in aid of local people travelling to Romania with Habitat for Humanity and the Centre for Cancer Research and Cell Biology at QUB.Living Vintage is a travelling fashion show where models wear a magnicent collection of some of the most stylish haute couture of the forties and fties in a great atmosphere of fun and nostalgia.Owned by sisters Bridget Owens and Marian Keenan, Living Vintage is a not-for-profit organisation.All monies raised are donated to Cancer Research at Queens University Belfast and Habitat for Humanity.The evening will showcase day dresses, suits and evening wear and is rounded of with a stunning bridal show.Bridget said: ldquoLiving Vintage evenings are great fun with plenty of laughs and many happy nostalgic memories.ldquoWe are extremely proud of our collection of authentic forties and fties fashion and all the outfits are accessorised with the appropriate vintage hats, gloves, bags, jewellery and of course, seamed stockings. Of course, some local ladies will also be on the catwalk.Doors open .pm for show at . and tickets are available from Smythrsquos shop, Newcastle, and JRrsquoS, Main St Castlewellan or by ringing Alicia on   and Marianne on  ..prettyPhoto

title: Strictly dancing at Newcastle school
story: A NEWCASTLE primary school are to host a Strictly Come Dancing fundraiser to help raise money for the school.St Maryrsquos Primary School will be staging the night at Slieve Donard Resort and Spa next Saturday, May .Q Radiorsquos Ryan A promises to bring a pinch of razzmatazz to the dance extravaganza as hersquoll be acting as compere for the evening.Dancers include teachers, classroom assistants, parents and past pupils. There will be two fabulous dance demonstrations from European Argentina Tango champions, Anna Arriza DrsquoEste and Marco de Camillis, and  Irish dancing world champions Orlaith Bradley and David Carberry.Jenni Maguire, a teacher at the school, has been putting the dancers through their paces along with former All-Ireland Ballroom champion and choreographer Graham Jack.The event promises to be a great night of entertainment, says Graham,with demonstrations from the world champion Irish dancers to kick start the night followed by couples taking to the stage with a selection of Latin and ballroom dances.He said: ldquoI am really excited about our event. It is a great opportunity to bring the school and community together for what promises to be a real dance spectacular, while raising money for our school.ldquoI couldnrsquot do what these dancers have done. They deserve great credit for putting two dance routines together in such a short period of time.ldquoThe contestants seem to have enjoyed the build up. While there has been pressure due to the time scale in preparation and the work load involved, there have been no tears or tantrums.He added. ldquoThe practices have been good fun. There have been plenty of laughs. The iniduals and couples mix well and we all get on the best. But when the hard work needs to be done, they take it very seriously.Jenni said the couples have put in many hours of rehearsals, given freely of their time and have shown great dedication.She said: ldquoSome have revealed much hidden talent in rehearsals and head judge, UTVrsquos Rita Fitzgerald, will have a tough job on her hands but with the help of the  and votes by the audience on the night the Strictly Ball could be a closely fought battle.One of the contestants, Claire Toner, whose son Dylan is a P pupil at the school, said: ldquoI volunteered as I wanted to do something dferent. It was a case of challenging myself and trying something fun and exciting.One person who has taken it all in her stride is classroom assistant Rachel Lowey. A past pupil of the school, she is paired with another former pupil and friend Shane Kearney.She said: ldquoLike Claire, I wanted to learn something new. Never in a million years did I think Irsquod be dancing on the same stage as some of my old teachers and classroom assistants.None of the dancers have experienced formal dance training before and for some it has been very dficult attending the twice weekly rehearsals.ldquoAs enjoyable as itrsquos been, one Strictly is my limit, said school principal Philip Fusco. ldquoWe hope this will be a superb event, not just for the school community of St Maryrsquos.ldquoWe look forward to welcoming everyone on the night and I have no doubt every guest will leave with a spring in their step.Tickets are available from the school office and are priced at pound for adult sand pound concession. You can also show your support and make a donation through JustGiving page.Many of the businesses, parents, friends and family have already shown their support by sponsoring a dancer.
